contents: When Gilman was a young child, (19) <u>her father leaves the family</u>. Gilman’s aunts assisted the family of three. One of these aunts, Harriet Beecher Stowe, wrote the acclaimed novel Uncle Tom’s Cabin, and another aunt, Isabella Beecher Hooker, was a suffragist. While her mother was not affectionate, Gilman developed intellectually in this environment. She taught herself to read when she was five years old, and she studied at the library. Many of her friends were boys, and Gilman was a self-identified tomboy. Gilman moved from school to school, and although she was intelligent, her studies suffered. (20) <u>Gilman’s mother was left with two children, Charlotte and her older brother.</u>
